thread.title: Arizona Coyotes try to fix slow starts during slump
thread.title_full: Arizona Coyotes try to fix slow starts during slump

author: azcentral.com
title: Arizona Coyotes try to fix slow starts during slump
text:
OTTAWA – If the Coyotes could reassemble the current order of a game, disconnecting the periods like puzzle pieces to try a new design, they might choose to lead with their effort in the second period or perhaps the third.
Through two weeks of games, Arizona has certainly showed the ability to improve as the action ages – even rallying in the final minute Tuesday against the Devils to bank their lone point so far on a five-game road trip that continues Saturday against the Senators.
But even amid other culprits, poor starts have headlined their struggles during a four-game winless skid.
“We need to be consistent every shift,” defenseman Nicklas Grossmann said. “We can’t take a period off and then play good for two periods, or we can’t start slow and end off strong. It’s not going to work.”
AZCENTRAL
Coyotes fall apart in third in loss to Rangers
At first blush, the first period doesn’t appear as a complete letdown.
The Coyotes have tallied seven goals in the opening 20 minutes – the fourth-highest total entering play Friday. Even more flattering, they’ve given up only two goals in the first.
But dig a little deeper and the trouble spots become magnified.
“There’s more to it than just putting the pucks in the net,” coach Dave Tippett said.
AZCENTRAL
Arizona Coyotes' Duclair succeeding after trade from NY
Clearly, the Coyotes have had difficulty even managing shots on goal, not registering their first until late in the opening period in each of their past two games. That’s a microcosm of other issues – scrambles in their own zone, transition plays that get turned around in a hurry and spotty execution when the team does generate an offensive opportunity.
“I think we have to stop doing turnovers in the neutral zone,” center Martin Hanzal said. “That’s the biggest key. We were pretty bad the last couple games with that, just trying to do the amazing play and highlight play every time. Sometimes you have to keep it simple – get it deep (and) go after pucks.”
Speed is another important ingredient, but it can be sabotaged by these types of misplays. The pace at which the Coyotes played in their first three wins was a noticeable improvement off of the standard set last season, but it can disappear quickly if other areas aren’t clicking.
AZCENTRAL
Arizona Coyotes XTRA app: Get latest news, scores
“When you don’t manage the puck very well and you turn it over, you can be the fastest skating team in the history of hockey and you still look slow,” Tippett said.
What should be encouraging to the Coyotes is the fact they've shown flashes of the style they want to define their play. Even in Thursday’s 4-1 loss to the Rangers, they were in control at times in the second period and had 16 of their 35 total shots in the third.
But they’re still searching for consistency from start to finish.
“It’s frustrating,” Hanzal said. “If you can play better in the second and third, it means we’re not tired or anything like that. We have to bring it every night and play all 60 minutes. That’s the key in the NHL right now. It’s so tough to win hockey games, especially if you only play two periods. It’s something we have to change.”
AZCENTRAL
Coyotes catch up with Yandle for first time since trade
Ice chip
The Coyotes held a video meeting Friday before the majority of players took to the ice for practice.
Center Antoine Vermette did not skate. He left Thursday’s game with a lower-body injury and will be reevaluated Saturday, Tippett said.
Reach the reporter at sarah.mclellan@arizonarepublic.com or 602-444-8276. Follow her at twitter.com/azc_mclellan.
Coyotes at Senators
When: 4 p.m.
Where: Canadian Tire Centre.
TV/radio: None/KMVP-FM (98.7).
Senators update: The Senators are winless in their past three games, losing their past two in a shootout. Overall, Ottawa is 3-2-2. Four players (forwards Kyle Turris, Mike Hoffman and Mark Stone and defenseman Erik Karlsson) are tied for the team lead in points with eight. Turris and Hoffman boast a team-high four goals apiece. With 3.14 goals-per-game, the Senators’ offense sits in the top 10 among all NHL teams. But their 2.86 goals-against average entered action Friday fourth-worst.
